questions.text: A 27-year-old man comes to the physician with his wife because they have been unable to conceive. They have had regular unprotected sex for the past 18 months without using contraception. His wife has been tested and is fertile. The patient began puberty at the age of 13 years. He has been healthy except for infection with Chlamydia trachomatis 10 years ago, which was treated with azithromycin. He is a professional cyclist and trains every day for 3–4 hours. His wife reports that her husband has often been stressed since he started to prepare for the national championships a year ago and is very conscious about his diet. His temperature is 36.5°C (97.7°F), pulse is 50/min, and blood pressure is 154/92 mm Hg. Physical examination of the husband shows an athletic stature with uniform inflammatory papular eruptions of the face, back, and chest. Genital examination shows small testes. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's infertility?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Cushing syndrome is a known risk factor for infertility. Hypercortisolism inhibits the release of gonadotropin-releasing hormone, which in turn results in reduced spermatogenesis. Reduced libido and erectile dysfunction can also occur. This diagnosis can generally be ruled out based on clinical features. While this patient's acne and hypertension are features of Cushing syndrome, other features such as muscle weakness, thinning of the skin, central obesity, sleep disturbances, and reduced libido would also be present.

B) CORRECT:

Anabolic steroids are the performance-enhancing drugs most commonly used by athletes to improve muscle mass and strength. Chronic anabolic steroid use can result in secondary hypogonadism due to the negative feedback of androgens on the hypothalamic-pituitary axis (↓ LH, ↓ FSH). This can lead to reduced spermatogenesis and abnormal sperm motility, causing infertility. Small testes, as seen in this patient, are a common finding. Uniform papular eruptions (steroid acne), hypertension, and the very muscular physique of this patient also indicate anabolic steroid use. A low sperm count would support the diagnosis.

Sperm count and testicular size typically return to normal a few months after discontinuation of anabolic steroids, although azoospermia may persist for several years.

C) INCORRECT:

Scrotal hyperthermia is a weak risk factor for infertility that acts by reducing spermatogenesis and resulting in reduced sperm viability. Cycling training requiring long periods on a bicycle saddle can cause prolonged periods of heat due to friction in the genital area, which could be a contributing factor to this patient's infertility. However, this does not account for the patient's small testes, hypertension, and acne. Other causes of scrotal hyperthermia include varicocele and the use of laptop computers on the lap.

D) INCORRECT:

Primary hypertension can cause erectile dysfunction, which affects the ability to conceive. Arterial hypertension is a very unlikely diagnosis in a young, athletic patient. On the contrary, it is generally associated with advanced age, a history of smoking, and physical inactivity. This patient's hypertension is much more likely to be secondary to the same cause as his infertility.

E) INCORRECT:

Chlamydia infection, one of the most common sexually transmitted infections in the US, can result in infertility. Particularly asymptomatic infections that go undetected can result in obstruction of the ductus deferens and subsequent azoospermia. While this patient has a history of chlamydia infection, it is unlikely to be the underlying cause of his infertility because his infection was treated appropriately. In addition, it would not explain the patient's small testes, hypertension, and acne.

F) INCORRECT:

Infertility due to secondary hypogonadism is a known complication of anorexia nervosa. High pressure sport careers are associated with an increased incidence of anorexia, and although the patient exhibits signs of restrictive eating and excessive exercise, this is not sufficient to suspect anorexia nervosa. Patients typically present with signs of starvation and malnutrition, such as hypothermia, dry skin, hair loss, muscle wasting, bradycardia, hypotension, and electrolyte disturbances. Furthermore, the condition is also much more common in women than in men.

G) INCORRECT:

Erectile dysfunction is the most common sexual disorder in men. Although it is most commonly secondary to an organic cause (e.g., diabetic neuropathy, antidepressants, trauma), it can also be psychogenic, occurring secondary to depression, anxiety (performance-related), relationship issues, and stress. The couple report that they have regular intercourse, making this diagnosis unlikely. In addition, it would not explain the patient's small testes, hypertension, and acne.

H) INCORRECT:

Kallmann syndrome is a rare, genetic form of infertility due to hypogonadotropic hypogonadism. It is more common in men and presentation varies according to the underlying mutation. Classic signs in male patients include absent puberty or delayed, partial puberty with reduced muscle mass, small stature, small testes, and absent or scarce body hair growth. Anosmia would also be expected. Although this patient has small testes, no other characteristic signs are present.
questions.hint: This patient's infertility is most likely related to his career as a professional cyclist.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man comes to the physician because he and his wife have been unable to conceive despite regular unprotected sex for the past 15 months without using contraception. His wife has been tested and is fertile. The patient began puberty at the age of 14 years. He was treated for Chlamydia trachomatis 6 years ago. He is a professional cyclist and trains every day for 3–4 hours. He feels stressed because of an upcoming race. His blood pressure is 148/92 mm Hg. Physical examination of the husband shows a tall, athletic stature with uniform inflammatory papular eruptions of the face, back, and chest. Genital examination shows small testes. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's infertility?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Erectile dysfunction is the most common sexual disorder in men. Although it is most commonly secondary to an organic cause (e.g., diabetic neuropathy, antidepressants, trauma), it can also be psychogenic, occurring secondary to depression, anxiety (performance-related), relationship issues, and stress. The couple report that they have regular intercourse, making this diagnosis unlikely. In addition, it would not explain the patient's small testes, hypertension, and acne.

B) INCORRECT:

Kallmann syndrome is a rare, genetic form of infertility caused by decreased production of GnRH from the hypothalamus, leading to hypogonadotropic hypogonadism. It is more common in men and presentation varies according to the underlying mutation. Classic signs in male patients include absent puberty or delayed, partial puberty with reduced muscle mass, small stature, small testes, and absent or scarce body hair growth. Anosmia would also be expected. Although this patient has small testes, no other characteristic signs are present.

C) CORRECT:

Anabolic steroids are the performance-enhancing drugs most commonly used by athletes to improve muscle mass, strength, and recovery. Chronic anabolic steroid use can result in secondary hypogonadism due to the negative feedback of androgens on the hypothalamic-pituitary axis, which lowers LH and FSH levels. A lower FSH level leads to reduced spermatogenesis in Sertoli cells. Reduced LH decreases the Leydig cell production of gonadal testosterone, which is also important for spermatogenesis. Reduced testosterone results in smaller testes as well. Uniform papular eruptions (steroid acne) and hypertension in this patient further support anabolic steroid use as the cause of his infertility. A low sperm count would also be expected.

D) INCORRECT:

Chlamydia infection, one of the most common STIs in the US, can result in infertility. Particularly asymptomatic infections that go undetected/untreated can result in obstruction of the ductus deferens (azoospermia) in male patients. While this patient has a history of chlamydia infection, it is unlikely to be the underlying cause of his infertility because his infection was properly treated. In addition, it would not explain the patient's small testes, hypertension, and acne.

E) INCORRECT:

Scrotal hyperthermia is a weak risk factor for infertility that acts by reducing spermatogenesis and resulting in reduced sperm viability. Cycling training requiring long periods on a bicycle saddle can cause prolonged periods of heat due to friction in the genital area, which could be a contributing factor to this patient's infertility. However, this does not account for the patient's small testes, hypertension, and acne.

Other causes of scrotal hyperthermia include varicocele and the use of laptop computers on the lap rather than a desk or table.

F) INCORRECT:

Klinefelter syndrome is a genetic disorder due to inheritance of an additional X chromosome, usually resulting in male sterility via decreased testosterone production and spermatogenesis. Although this patient's tall stature and small testes correspond with this diagnosis, most patients do not reach full sexual maturity and have features of scarce facial/body hair, gynecomastia, and some cognitive impairments, which are not seen in this patient.
questions.hint: This patient's infertility is related to his career as a professional athlete.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old man with a history of beta-thalassemia and secondary hemochromatosis presents with symptoms of low testosterone and is confirmed to have secondary hypogonadism. Physical examination is unremarkable.
Compared with other modes of testosterone replacement, the use of intramuscular testosterone injections is associated with an increased risk of which one of the following adverse effects?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Virilization of intimate partners is a potential risk from transdermal testosterone gels.

B) INCORRECT:

Testosterone replacement of any form will lead to infertility; if infertility is already present, testosterone replacement will not restore fertility. Gonadotropin administration would be necessary if fertility were desired.

C) INCORRECT:

Hepatoma and other hepatic adverse effects, including jaundice and hepatic cysts, were seen with older formulations of oral testosterone; modern oral testosterone formulations do not have this concern. Despite the greater safety of the modern oral testosterone formulations, these are not frequently used due to cost and an association with the development of hypertension.

D) INCORRECT:

Anemia is not a side effect of testosterone therapy; in fact, any form of testosterone treatment stimulates erythrocyte production. Intramuscular injections may be more likely than other forms of testosterone therapy to cause erythrocytosis, although this would be less of a concern in a patient with beta-thalassemia than in other patients.

E) CORRECT:

Common forms of testosterone replacement are transdermal gel and intramuscular injection. A major drawback of intramuscular injection is the potential for fluctuating mood and libido related to supraphysiologic testosterone levels immediately after injection, followed by declining levels until the next dose. There may also be pain at the injection site.

Key learning point: Among the methods of administration of testosterone replacement for hypogonadal men, the one that causes the most fluctuation in mood and libido is intramuscular injection.

questions.text:
An 18-year-old man presents with a wrist fracture after a minor fall from standing height. He reports two previous fractures with minimal trauma in the past year and notes decreased libido and sparse facial hair. On examination, he appears thin and has small testes. Vital signs are normal. Laboratory studies reveal normal serum calcium, phosphate, and alkaline phosphatase levels.
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in evaluating this patient’s condition?

choices.text: Measure morning testosterone and gonadotropin levels and obtain a DEXA scan

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Pituitary MRI is indicated for suspected central hypogonadism with symptoms like headaches or visual disturbances. The patient's presentation suggests primary hypogonadism, with normal bone metabolic markers and no signs of pituitary involvement, making MRI unnecessary at this stage.

B) INCORRECT:

Vitamin D deficiency typically presents with abnormal calcium, phosphate, and alkaline phosphatase levels, which are normal in this patient. The clinical signs of decreased libido, sparse facial hair, and small testes suggest hypogonadism, not vitamin D deficiency.

C) INCORRECT:

Recombinant parathyroid hormone therapy is used for osteoporosis with severe bone loss, typically in older adults. The patient's normal serum calcium, phosphate, and alkaline phosphatase levels do not indicate a primary metabolic bone disorder. The clinical presentation suggests hypogonadism, not a condition warranting parathyroid hormone therapy.

D) CORRECT:

The patient presents with signs of hypogonadism, such as decreased libido, sparse facial hair, and small testes, along with recurrent low-impact fractures. Hypogonadism can lead to decreased bone density due to low testosterone levels. Measuring morning testosterone levels, when they are at their peak, is crucial for accurate assessment. Evaluating gonadotropin levels helps differentiate between primary and secondary hypogonadism. A dual-energy x-ray absorptiometry (DEXA) scan is necessary to assess bone mineral density, as hypogonadism can lead to osteoporosis. Normal serum calcium, phosphate, and alkaline phosphatase levels suggest that the bone issues are not due to a primary metabolic bone disorder.

Key learning point: In young males with fragility fractures and signs of hypogonadism, testosterone and gonadotrophin levels should be assessed, and a DEXA scan should be performed to evaluate bone mineral density.
